description.narrative: Armed Violence Prevention
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
The armed violence prevention mechanisms instituted in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

comment.narrative: The armed violence prevention has not yet been applied as an operational concept in BiH. Although different components of armed violence prevention are being addressed as distinct, human security challenges, a comprehensive, multi-sectoral, approach to preventing armed violence has not yet been pursued by the authorities.

Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Dialogue and Peacebuilding Platform developed. 2. % of population that benefited from improved dialogue and enhanced appreciation of diversity in the targeted areas across the country. 3. Strengthened youth participation in policy development and governmental initiatives. 5. Nation-wide youth network established dedicated to intercultural understanding and dialogue. 6. comment.narrative: 1. No Dialogue Platform. 2. TBD in 2014 by baseline assessments of current state of play regarding dialogue and respect of diversity. 3. Number captured through baseline analysis at the start of the project. 4. Assessment of existing youth participatory mechanisms. 5. No dedicated youth network. 6. Perception recorded in 2008 and 2012: All youth responses (%): - At work, in school or college 80% (2008), 88% (2012); - In the family or household 61% (2008), 70% (2012); - In the local community 89% (2008), 97% (2012); - In political organisations or NGOs 90% (2008), 99% (2012); - Amongst peers and friends 66% (2008), 80% (2012).

1. All elements of the dialogue platform functioning. 2. 20% of population improved dialogue and mutual understanding through Grants Facility awarded community projects. 3. Number increased by at least 10 % by the end of the project. 4. At least 3 sessions/conferences organized through platform for the duration of the programme; establish new or strengthen existing youth participation mechanisms/channels with the government. 5. Network members from all parts of the country, at least 3 initiatives instigated by the network for duration of the project. 6. Perception At work, in school or college 78% - In the family or household 60% - In the local community 87% - In political organisations or NGOs 90% - Amongst peers and friends 70%.

description.narrative: Assistance to Bosnia and Herzegovina in the preparation of its third National Communication (TNC) for the implementation of the obligations under the United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change.

Assistance to Bosnia and Herzegovina in the preparation of its Third National Communication (TNC) for the implementation of the obligations under the United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change (UNFCCC).

1. TNC (Third National Communications) submitted to UNFCCC (United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change) 2. - The greenhouse gases (GHG) inventory capacity for data collection and analysis process maintained and strengthened - The greenhouse gases (GHG) inventory for years 2001-2009 and 2012-2013 completed 3. - Strengthened Vulnerability and Adaptation (V&A) Team - Updated and strengthened chapter on Vulnerability and Adaptation (V&A) 4. - Updated and strengthened chapter on Mitigation - Registration of BiH National Appropriate Mitigation actions (NAMAs) enabled 5. - Updated account of National Circumstances prepared and capacity to collect and manage information strengthened - Technology Needs Assessment completed - TNC (Third National Communication) prepared, translated and edited, submitted and disseminated

comment.narrative: 1. BiH submitted its Second National Communication (SNC) to UNFCCC (United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change) Secretariat in Nov 2013 2. - Inventory for the period 1990-2001 carried out by independent consultants - Inventory for 2010-2011 in progress - Not all emissions from energy, industrial and waste sectors covered - Several gases not measured - Need for revision of coal emission factors 3. - Set of environmental indicators not established in BiH - Lack of data on flood and draught - Discussion of vulnerability and impacts in the SNC (Second National Communications) is primarily qualitative in nature - No studies on climate change (CC) impact in tourism and health sectors 4. - Business as Usual scenario and two mitigation scenarios till 2025 developed under SNC (Second National Communications) project - No National Appropriate Mitigation actions (NAMA) approving authority established for BiH - No NAMA (National Appropriate Mitigation actions) created for BiH 5. - National Communication (NC) described in SNC (Second National Communications), but information on technology, finance and capacity needs, require further elaboration - No Technology Needs Assessment (TNA) undertaken in BiH

1. Greenhouse gases inventory for the years 2001-2009 and 2012-2013 completed 2. Registration of BiH NAMAs (National Appropriate Mitigation Actions) enabled and at least 3 project proposal ideas prepared 3. Technology Needs Assessment conducted, prepared, circulated and discussed at a thematic workshop (with experts and relevant ministry representatives)

1. Draft Greenhouse gases inventory for the years 2001-2009 and 2012-2013 completed 2. Registration of BiH NAMAs (National Appropriate Mitigation Actions) enabled and at least 2 project proposal ideas prepared 3. Technology Needs Assessment conducted, prepared, circulated and discussed at a thematic workshop (with experts and relevant ministry representatives)

description.narrative: Indicator 1: Number of MZs engaged in and contributing to the definition of a new vision for MZs in BiH. Indicator 2: Number of socio-economic stakeholders (disaggregated by sex), including socially excluded and vulnerable groups and women engaged in and contributing to the definition of a new vision for MZs in BiH. Indicator 3: Level of acceptance of the new vision for MZs by formally established consultative bodies. Indicator 4: % of citizens (disaggregated by sex) in selected partner municipalities familiar with the new MZ vision and willing to engage in its realization. Indicator 5.: Number of MZs within target municipalities effectively engaged in local policy design and delivery cycle. Indicator 6.: Number of MZs within target municipal governments which increase organizational and technical capacity. Indicator 7.: Number of MZs lacking basic operating conditions.

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: No comprehensive project document available (2014). Baseline 2: 0 (2015). Baseline 3: Insufficient (2015). Baseline 4. 360 (2015) . Baseline 5: 0 (2015). baseline 6: 0 (2015). .

1.Select participating local communities and local governments and conduct baseline surveys, including citizenâ€™s satisfaction survey. 2. Conduct Regional comparative review to identify successful institutional and legal frameworks for community governance to serve as platform for country-wide discussion on the future role of local communities in Bosnia and Herzegovina and possible regulatory changes.

1. Comprehensive questionnaire for the assessment and baseline of the local communities and local governments was designed and public call for expression of interest among 84 local governments has been launched. 2. Regional comparative review has been drafted.

1. At least 10 Municipalities and 60 MZs selected for participation in programme 2. At least 60 MZ engaged in and contributed to the definition of a new vision for MZs in BiH representing effectively around 90,000 citizens 3. 1 study visit organized for key stakeholders, with at least 40% female participants. 4. 750 social and economic stakeholders, socially excluded groups, and women engaged in and contributed to the definition of a new vision for MZs in BiH. 5. Analytical report on MZs, including comparative review of legal frameworks in BiH and other countries prepared and widely disseminated
6. 10 municipalities and at least 60 MZs are selected based on a set of criteria. 7. 60 MZs within target local governments effectively engaged in local policy design and delivery cycle. 8. 60 MZ leaders and staff who strengthen their organizational capacity and skills. 9. 2 tailored and interactive training programmes designed and delivered to target groups. 10. 600 CSO and MZ activists within target areas receive training or coaching, including at least 40% women and 10% representatives of socially excluded groups. 11. Basic operating condition improved in at least 40 MZ

description.narrative: UN CT response to BIH floods May 2014
Revival of public services, facilities, communal infrastructure and livelihoods in flood-affected local communities in Bosnia and Herzegovina
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Increased sustainability and resilience of the flood affected population and institutions through targeted assistance in a number of vital recovery areas: 1500 households assisted with animal feed for early recovery 17 most affected health centers equipped with medical equipment and vehicles 100 households received greenhouses 7 public water utility companies restored their water and sanitation systems dairy value chain improved in the canton zenica-doboj through targeted assistance to affected households and reconstruction of milk collection points and farms

comment.narrative: The natural disaster affected a quarter of the territory approximately one million people and some 27% of the country's population of 3.8 million. Nearly 50%of municipalities were hit by the floods, 46 of which have suffered severe damage and destruction, where urban, industrial and rural areas were completely flooded with water, cut off and without electricity, drinkable water or communication for days. Some 50,000 homes have been damaged or flooded leading to evacuation of 40,000 persons and loss of over 15,000 persons.

1500 households assisted with animal feed for early recovery 17 most affected health centers equipped with medical equipment and vehicles 76 households received greenhouses 7 public water utility companies restored their water and sanitation systems dairy value chain improved in the canton zenica-doboj through targeted assistance to affected households and reconstruction of milk collection points and farms

description.narrative: EU flood recovery programme
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Indicator for Objective 1: Number of dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired (target value: 4,000). Number of vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home (target value: 15,400). Number of comprehensive National Risk Assessment surveys conducted
Indicator for Objective 2: Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Number of educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped: target value Number of children benefiting from rehabilitated and reequipped educational infrastructure in affected areas Number of municipal public administration facilities in affected areas rehabilitated Number of citizens benefiting from restored/improved municipal administrative service delivery in flood-affected areas Number of healthcare facilities in affected areas rehabilitated Number of citizens benefiting from restored/improved healthcare services in affected areas Number of social welfare facilities in flood-affected areas rehabilitated Number of representatives of vulnerable groups in affected areas benefiting from restored/improved social services Number of child-friendly spaces constructed to ensure temporary learning and playing facilities for children in affected areas Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure km of local roads and number of bridges in flood-affected areas rehabilitated Number of flood-affected local governments benefitting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Number of critical water and sanitation facilities in flood-affected areas reconstructed Number of households in flood-affected areas benefiting directly from improved water and sanitation services.
Indicator for Objective 3: Number of jobs in agriculture and local businesses retained or created in affected areas Number of MSMEs supported to restore economic activity Number of a

comment.narrative:
Baseline for Objective 1: 39,231 damaged homes in BiH.
Baseline for Objective 2: 120 educational facilities, 8 municipal buildings damaged; Recovery Needs Assessment and based on data recorded by the enterprise survey, an additional 33,500 wage workers were directly affected by the floods and are at immediate risk. Additional information received after the conclusion of the enterprise survey by the Ministry of Labour and Veterans of RS stated that approximately 20,000 jobs remain at risk in RS due to the flood.
Baseline for Objective 3: 81 affected local governments benefiting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Recovery Needs Assessment (2014).

Targets for Objective 1: 3,400 dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired (target value: 4,400). 11,900 vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home/resume life in normal living conditions Comprehensive National Risk Assessment surveys conducted
Targets for Objective 2: 47 educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped 4 flood-affected locations mitigated in terms of landslide and flood risk 10 rehabilitated public buildings with increased energy efficiency 45,000 children benefiting from rehabilitated and reequipped educational infrastructure in affected areas 3 municipal public administration facilities in affected areas rehabilitated 210,000 citizens benefiting from restored/improved municipal administrative service delivery in flood-affected areas. 2 healthcare facilities in affected areas rehabilitated 210,000 citizens benefiting from restored/improved healthcare services in affected areas 1 social welfare facility in flood-affected areas rehabilitated 55,000 representatives of vulnerable groups in affected areas benefiting from restored/improved social services 4 child-friendly spaces constructed to ensure temporary learning and playing facilities for 2, 000 children in affected areas and number of children benefiting 11 km of local roads and bridges (in total number of 74) in flood-affected areas rehabilitated 25 critical water and sanitation facilities in flood-affected areas reconstructed
Targets for objective 3: 1,674 jobs in agriculture and local businesses retained or created in affected areas 39 MSMEs supported to restore economic activity 700 commercial agriculture households linked into the local market value chain (grain producers, subsistence farmers, poultry farmers and raspberry producers)

description.narrative: Seeking Care, Support and Justice for Survivors of Conflict Related Sexual Violence in BiH
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

1. Number of workshops with judiciary, police media and NGOs aimed at enhancing services and addressing the needs of CRSV survivors. 2. Number of FLA services for CRSV victims established in selected municipalities in BiH 3. Number of CRSV associations economically empowered and supported through targeted interventions.

comment.narrative: 1. Existing services are fragmented and lacking capacity and awareness of the needs of CRSV victims and adding an additional stigma to those who try to claim their rights. 2. FLA services not specifically designed to address the needs of CRSV victims. 3. Weak economic empowerment of CRSV victims.

1. Seven workshops organized and held with judiciary, police media and NGOs aimed at enhancing services and addressing the needs of CRSV survivors. 2. Two FLA service providers for CRSV victims established in selected municipalities in BiH. 3. Two CRSV associations economically empowered and supported through targeted interventions

title.narrative: Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin

description.narrative: Technology transfer for climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin

title.narrative: Technology transfer for climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin

description.narrative: Technology transfer for climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin
Energy - policy, planning and administration

Project started in 2015.
1. Number of new technologies transferred to Bosnia and Herzegovina as part of a methodology for strategic flood risk management. 2. Vrbas river basin (12% of BiH territory) covered by an automated hydrometric monitoring network for effective Flood Forecasting and Early Warning. 3. Policy environment and regulatory framework for adaptation related technology transfer established or strengthened 4. Strengthened Capacity to transfer appropriate adaptation technologies 5. Number of institutions enabled to modify risk management strategies based on introduced vulnerability, loss and damages assessment and improved hydrometric monitoring technologies 6. Number of people in target basin benefiting from flood risk management adaptation technologies, tools, and adaptation strategies, and are less exposed to flood risk 7. Availability of innovative non-structural measures introduced and implemented as part of climate adaptation strategies to provide improved resilience to communities (include agric. 8. Number of communities benefitting from introduced forecasting, early warning, response and recovery technologies to support local communities at risk of flooding

comment.narrative:
Project started in 2015.
1. 0 strategic flood risk management technologies in Bosnia and Herzegovina 2. No automatized and centralized hydrometric network in Vrbas river basin 3. No policy/regulatory framework for adaptation related technology transfer in place 4. Local professionals are unaware of adaptation technologies 5. Most of the socio-economic information required to assess flood damages, losses, exposure and vulnerability is not currently available and is not collected systematically and gender-disaggregation of data not systematically done. 6.Current approach limited of inclusion of local communities, and particularly the vulnerable groups 7.Current approach to flood risk management is structural flood protection measures and non-structural measures are not considered to be adaptive measure. 8. 0 communities benefitting from introduced forecasting, early warning, response and recovery technologies to support local communities at risk of flooding.

Project started in 2015
1. Establish inter-agency working group on climate changes and flood risk management 2. Rehabilitate hydro-metric network in Vrbas River Basin 3. Complete modeling on climate change impact in Vrbas River Basin 4. Develop spatial data infrastructure for Vrbas River Basin

1. Inter-agency working group on climate changes and flood risk management consisting of representatives of water agencies, hydro-meteorological institutes and geodetic institutes established. 2. Hydro-metric network in Vrbas River Basin, consisting of 28 gauges, established. 3. Models on climate change impact in Vrbas River Basin developed. 4. Spatial data infrastructure, including geoportal, for Vrbas River Basin established.

comment.narrative: 1. Promote in-country and abroad the tourism potentials of Via Dinarica in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 2. Support small businesses, bed-and-breakfasts, tourism organizations along the Via Dinarica Trails through livelihood/income generation opportunities to increase their productive economics. 3. Continue with assessment and charting of the Via Dinarica Trails. 4. Support tourism organisations/tour operators along the Via Dinarica Trails to strengthen their management practices and customer service capacity. 5. Further promote Via DInarica in Bosnia and Herzegovina through website and social media. 6. Assist relevant stakeholders in the design of tourism packages (outdoor/adventure packages, regional tours).

description.narrative: Support to flood recovery and disaster risk mitigation and management in Bosnia and Herzegovina

title.narrative: Landslide Disaster Risk Management in Bosnia and Herzegovina_rev
Landslides Disasster and Floods Risk Mangement in BiH project

description.narrative: The project aims to strengthen capacities of local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina for landslide risk mitigation. The intervention will provide support to 9 landslide- and flood-affected local governments to remediate and stabilise landslides.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: Project started in 2015. 1. 3,000 2. 12,500 3. 0 4. 0 5. 0 (Insufficient) 6. 0

Project started in 2015. 1. At least 10 landslides covering at least 600,000 m2 are remediated within partner local governments. 2. At least 4,400 people and 1,200 housing units with restored safe living conditions and livelihoods by end of March 2016. 3. 9 local governments put land risk mitigation implementation measures in place by the end of March 2016. 4. At least 1 standard practical manual disseminated to all local governments. 5. At least 27 local government staff from target local governments received practical technical and training assistance. 6. Landslide Institutional and Policy Analysis for Bosnia and Herzegovina conducted.

Project started in 2015. 1. 9 landslides are rehabilitated within partner local governments. 2. More than 300 housing units with restored safe living conditions and livelihoods by end of 2015. 3. 9 local governments trained and equipped for establishment of landslide risk cadasters

description.narrative: 1. Number of TB cases (all forms) notified to the national health authorities during a specified period (output level) 2. Number of notified cases of bacteriologically confirmed TB (new and relapse) 3. Treatment success rate- all forms: Percentage of all forms of TB cases (i.e. bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed) successfully treated (cured plus treatment completed) among all forms of TB cases registered for treatment during a specified period 4. Treatment success rate- bacteriologically confirmed: Percentage of bacteriologically confirmed TB cases successfully treated (cured plus treatment completed) among the bacteriologically confirmed TB cases registered for treatment during a specified period 5. Number of TB cases (all forms) notified among vulnerable population (Roma, IDPs, prisoners, poor and young living in appalling conditions and elderly) 6. Percentage of reporting units implementing electronic reporting system and submitting timely reports 7. Number of TB doctors, microbiologists and lab technicians trained/retrained in TB issues 8. Number and percentage of laboratories showing adequate performance in external quality assurance for culture among the laboratories that undertake these activities during the reporting period 9. TB cases with results for diagnostic drug susceptibility testing for MDR-TB among those eligible for drug susceptibility testing according to national policy during the specified period of assessment (number and percentage) 10. Number of laboratory-confirmed MDR-TB cases enrolled on second-line anti-TB treatment during the specified period of assessment 11. Percentage of MDR-TB cases initiated on a second-line anti-TB treatment who have a negative culture at the end of 6 months of treatment during the specified period of assessment. 12. Number of TB patients supervised by polyvalent patronage nurses (PPN) 13. Number of Roma people reached with TB sessions provided by outreach workers

Fighting corruption Interim response
Anti corruption

1. Percentage of respondents in Bosnia and Herzegovina feel that Parliament and Public Officials and Servants are corruption/extremely corrupt increase 2. Level of corruption in Bosnia and Herzegovina in 2016 (as compared to 2014).

comment.narrative: 1. In 2013, 67 % of respondents in Bosnia and Herzegovina felt that Parliament and Public Officials and Civil Servants are corrupt/extremely corrupt. 2. Bosnia and Herzegovina is on the 80th place out of 175 countries on the level of corruption in 2014.

Inclusive & sustainable Economic Development Project
policy, planning and administration

1. Number of value chains analysed and effectively supported to increase productivity. 2. Percentage increase in productivity in selected value chains. 3. Percentage increase in average gross revenue per unit of production. 4. Number of returnee families included in selected value chains.

comment.narrative: 1. 0 2. Low productivity in agricultural / food producing value chains. 3. Average personal income EUR 395. 4. 0

1. Ensure at least 5% increase in productivity in selected 6 value chains through linkage of at least 6 new SMEs to the value chains, support to 5 agricultural service providers and assistance for better marketing and promotion. 2. Ensure at least 10 % increase in average gross revenue per unit of production. 3. Ensure at least 5 % increase in average gross revenue per unit of production. 4. Support at least 20 additional returnees and IDPs by engagement in income generation activities.

description.narrative: Local Democracy Phase IV
Local Democracy Phase IV
Other General Services - support to civil society

comment.narrative: 1. Despite existing political intent and commitment, as well as support from the international community, civil society engagement with local authorities remains inadequate and fragmented. 2. Civil society development and establishment of stronger ties between citizens and the State are hindered by weak capacities of local authorities and CSOs, limited understanding of mutual roles and responsibilities, and a lack of transparent mechanisms for disbursement of CSO funds

1. Launch at least 5 Public calls for CSOs in close collaboration with partner municipalities (at least one Call per municipality), 2. At least 20 CSO representatives trained in relation to PCM and LOD Methodology, 3. At least 6 municipalities introduced mechanisms for funds disbursement for CSOs, 4. 6 municipalities institutionalized monitoring in their work with CSOs, 5. At least one successful and transparent municipal call for CSO proposals is executed by each partner municipality using LOD Methodology,
6. 20 municipal employees went through project management trainings, 7. 640,000 USD of grants disbursed to at least 10 CSO projects, 8. CSO projects serviced at least 2 000 beneficiaries.

1. Nine Public Calls for CSOs launched in competitively selected LSUs and one Public Calls from CSOs repeated (in directly selected partner municipalities), 2. 144 CSO representatives trained in relation to PCM and LOD Methodology, 3. 7 municipalities institutionalised mechanisms for funds disbursement for CSOs in 2015, 4. Targets regarding establishment of the monitoring mechanisms in partner municipalities moved to 2016 targets (ongoing process â€“ results expected in beginning of 2016). 5. Five successful and transparent municipal call for CSO proposals executed in partner municipalities using LOD Methodology, (Visoko, Novo Sarajevo, Domaljevac, Bijeljina and Berkovici). In other partner LSUs transparent municipal call for CSO planned in 2016.
6. 36 municipal employees went through project management trainings, 7. 920,000 USD of grants disbursed to 63 CSO projects, 8. CSO projects serviced 6829 beneficiaries.

BiraÄ Region Advancement and Cooperation (BIRAC)
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

Number of functioning funding mechanism in support of regional development priorities. 4. Number farmers and micro producers with increased income as a result of project assistance.

comment.narrative: 1. Lack of formal mechanisms for inter-municipal cooperation, implementation and coordination of development interventions in the region. 2. 0 (no protocols of cooperation across social sectors, no referral mechanisms to address the needs of vulnerable children and families). 3. 0 functioning funding mechanism in support of regional development initiatives. 4. 0 5. 0 6. 0

1. Adoption of the BiraÄ region strategy supported. 2. 5 Social Protection Plans in 5 local governments designed and adopted. 3. Regional funding mechanism supported in the first cycle. 4. Assist local governments and the LAG BiraÄ in implementation of projects contributing directly to improved quality of life through small-scale community infrastructure initiatives within the 6 target local governments. 5. Assist improvement of social service delivery in 6 target localities. 6. Support income generation for farmers through livelihood support initiatives in 6 target localities.

policy, planning and administration

description.narrative:
Integrated Local Development Project Indicators: 1. % of local and cantonal governments with harmonized development planning framework; 2. Level of increased capacities of relevant institutional planning structures; 3. Number of public financial mechanisms supporting priorities originating from local strategies. 4. % of local governments applying an integrated local development management approach. 5. % of realization of the annual plans of local development strategies of partner local governments. 6. Number of citizens benefiting directly from improved local services as result of the project assistance. 7. Number of inter-municipal projects developed with the project support by mid-2015.
Municipal Training System Project indicators: 1. % of implementation of the entity Training Strategies for Local Government Employees. 2. Level of functionality of the established entity core public structures of the training system. 3. % of public financial resources allocated through various government levels enabling effective functioning of the training system for local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 4. Number of designed training programmes for local governments within the training system. 5. Number of local government employees who increase their capacity through training delivered through the training system. 6. Number of local governments who undertake reform measures towards establishment /strengthening of their HRM function.

comment.narrative:
Integrated Local Development Project baseline: 1. Local and cantonal strategic planning system is not harmonized and detached from the strategic planning frameworks and operational process of higher government levels. 2. Low development planning capacities of relevant institutional stakeholders. 3. 0 4. 5 % 5. 10 % 6. 0 7. 0
Municipal Training System Project baseline: 1. 0 % (2014). 2. Low 3. 0 4. 15 training programmes 5. 1000 6. 20

1. Further support finalization of strategic planning process in 9 partner cantonal governments based on the harmonized development planning approach; 2. Assist 2 relevant entity institutions to adopt relevant legal/by-law framework in the area of development planning; 3. Further assist relevant institutions to launch and manage the second cycle of the 2 public financial mechanisms supporting priorities originating from local strategies. 4. Assist 15 selected local governments to apply an integrated local development management approach, thus contribute to more effective realization of local strategies. 5. Assist local governments and relevant entity institutions to implement projects directly contributing to better service delivery for the citizens. 6. Support implementation of inter-municipal projects.
Municipal Training System Project: 1. Support implementation of the last year of the entity Training Strategies for Local Government Employees, as well as the design of the new generation of entity Training Strategies 2016 - 2020. 2. Continue to assist entity level public institutions to effectively manage the training system for local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 3. Support formalization and endorsement of public financial mechanisms ensuring sustainability of the training system. 4. Support the design of at least 5 new training programmes and their delivery to target groups. 5. Further assist at least 5 local governments to undertake reform measures towards establishment /strengthening of their HRM function.

description.narrative: EXPLODE

title.narrative: Grant Application Form to EUD BiH

description.narrative: Explosive Ordnance and Remnants of War Destruction (EXPLODE)
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

The high hazardous munitions and complex weapons systems are disposed of. The pace of ammunition destruction is increased. Capacities of the Ministry of Defense and Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina are improved and selected ammunition storage facilities are upgraded to be aligned with the international standards.

comment.narrative: There are 17,000 tonnes of ammunition surpluses that require urgent disposal. The capacities of the Ministry of Defense of Bosnia and Herzegovina for ammunition stockpile management are weak. The capacities for those interventions must be improved. The safety standards of storage facilities are to aligned with the international standards.

description.narrative: Disaster Risk Reduction in BIH

title.narrative: Project Document "Disaster Risk Reduction Initiative in Bosnia and Herzegovina"
Project document: Support to Flood Recovery and Risk Mitigation

description.narrative: Project will strengthen policy and institutional frameworks for DRR. Project will enhance existing capacities to build a reliable and efficient preparedness and response system and will build resilience of local communities.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.Number of organized disaster risk reduction platforms organized in BiH resulting in enhanced capacities of responsible institutions from all levels of government. 2. Number of educational events aimed at increased understanding of Disaster Risk Reduction and responsibilities of different actors in this area 3. Level of Capacities and conditions under which Civil Service Protection agencies in BiH operate. 4. Number of roaming dog management plans adopted in selected municipalities in BiH.

comment.narrative: 1. Disaster Risk Reduction policy of BiH is decentralized to all levels of government with different government levels without clear roles and responsibilities and with limited coordination. 2. Lack of understanding of Disaster Risk Reduction and responsibilities of different actors in this area. 3. Insufficient level of equipment at disposal by Civil Service Protection agencies in BiH 4. No roaming dog management plans adopted in Lopare and Sanski Most.

1. Develop one plan in the area of disaster risk reduction targeted at fire protection prevention activities. 2. Development of evidence based disaster risk profiles for seven cantons and four municipalities based on the existing national hazard risk assessment in BiH. 3. Development of Disaster Risk Reduction Training Programme and ToT Module integrating DRR into local policies and strategies. 4.Implementation of the Humane Community Development plans in municipalities of Sanski Most, Jajce and Gradacac 5. Assessment of capacities of City of Mostar in Humane Community Development. 6. Equipping of Vet clinics in Sanski Most, Jajce and Gradacac to undertake sterilization and castration in line with IFAW standards in humane handling with animals 7. Full implementation of Humane Community Development plan in Lopare and report from Municipality on achieved progress.

description.narrative: Early recovery and flood risk mitigation support to local communities in BIH by assisting the restoration of public sanitation services in 10 most affected localities and supporting technical flood defence measures
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Percentage of the target population protected by improved flood defenses in BiH priority localities. 2. Percentage of flood risk mitigation measures in BiH priority localities completed. 3. Percentage of project funded flood defenses in BiH priority localities assessed as 1) offering better than pre-flood levels of protection and 2) capable of withstanding a flood of similar size without any significant effect on the protected population. 4. Percentage of target population in BiH priority localities who have had their public sanitation services restored to at least pre-flood standards. 5. Number of de-silting and cleaning of wastewater pipe projects that are assessed as being on track against their delivery milestones and plans. 6. Number of wastewater (be it reconstruction, upgrades, desilting and cleaning) infrastructure projects assessed as being on track against its delivery milestones and plan. 7. Number of river dredging and cleaning projects are assessed as being on track against their delivery milestones and plans.

comment.narrative: 1. Finalized restoration of the functionality of public wastewater systems in eight municipalities, restoring the wastewater systems for 21,439 citizens, 7,996 households, 11 schools, 5 health institutions, 6 public buildings, 5 business enterprises and 2 city stadiums. 2. Finalized works on rehabilitation of water supply systems in two municipalities provides drinking water for more than 3,000 households 3. Finalized engineering works on structural flood risk reduction measures in 4 municipalities, reducing the flood risk for more than 7,000 households
